item.title: The most bizarre tech announced so far at CES 2026
item.dc:creator: Lauren Forristal
item.description: From an AI panda pet to an anime girl hologram for your desk, here are the wildest products at CES 2026.

item.title: LMArena lands $1.7B valuation four months after launching its product
item.dc:creator: Julie Bort
item.description: LMArena, which started as a UC Berkeley research project, has raised about $250 million total and become a unicorn in about seven months.

item.title: CES 2026: Follow live for the first official day with Ring, Mobileye, Siemens, robots, AI, and more
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Korosec, Sarah Perez
item.description: CES 2026, the annual consumer tech conference held in Las Vegas, is here. And lucky for you, we have TechCrunch editors and reporters on the ground to cover the news, scout out the interesting, weird, and relevant (and some not so relevant) tech, and of course the people working on it. Even before the official kickoff of CES on January 6, there will be product reveals from Amazon, Nvidia, Hyundai, AMD, and more. AI is at the center of most of the action. But this year, we're hearing a lot more about the convergence of AI and the physical world, whether it's in factories, robotics, or autonomous vehicles. Follow our live updates as we share all the reveals and new hardware as it happens.

item.title: Can a social app fix the ‘terrible devastation’ of social media?
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ha
item.description: Twitter co-founder Biz Stone and Pinterest co-founder Evan Sharp have raised new funding for a social media app that helps users "plan with intention."

item.title: How AI is reshaping work and who gets to do it, according to Mercor’s CEO
item.dc:creator: Theresa Loconsolo
item.description: Three-year-old startup Mercor has become a $10 billion middleman in AI’s data gold rush. The company connects AI labs like OpenAI and Anthropic with former employees of Goldman Sachs, McKinsey, and white-shoe law firms, paying them up to $200 an hour to share their industry expertise and train the AI models that could eventually automate their former employers out of business.   Today we’re bringing […]

item.title: Nvidia’s AI empire: A look at its top startup investments
item.dc:creator: Marina Temkin
item.description: Over the last two years, Nvidia has used its ballooning fortunes to invest in over 100 AI startups. Here are the giant semiconductor's largest investments.

item.title: The 16 top logistics, manufacturing, materials startups from Disrupt Startup Battlefield
item.dc:creator: Julie Bort
item.description: Here is the full list of the logistics, manufacturing, and materials Startup Battlefield 200 selectees, along with a note on what made us select them for the competition.

item.title: Even as global crop prices fall, India’s Arya.ag is attracting investors — and staying profitable
item.dc:creator: Jagmeet Singh
item.description: Arya.ag, an Indian agritech company offering storage facilities near farms and offering lending services to hundreds of thousands of farmers, has drawn investor interest and remained profitable even as global crop prices continue to fall in a volatile commodities market. The investor interest has taken shape in the latest all-equity Series D round from GEF […]

item.dc:creator: Julie Bort
item.description: Here is the full list of the media/entertainment Startup Battlefield 200 selectees, along with a note on what made us select them for the competition.

item.title: Fizz social app’s CEO on why anon works
item.dc:creator: Theresa Loconsolo
item.description: Fizz is betting that Gen Z is tired of performing their lives on Instagram and TikTok.   What started as a pandemic-era group chat frustration has turned into the dominant social platform on college campuses across the US, focused on the 99% of life that doesn’t make it into a highlight reel. Capturing the attention of a demographic typically glued […]

item.title: ‘College dropout’ has become the most coveted startup founder credential
item.dc:creator: Marina Temkin
item.description: AI founders are increasingly using their "dropout" status as a credential during YC pitches.

item.title: Tade Oyerinde and Teddy Solomon talk about building engaged audiences at TechCrunch Disrupt
item.dc:creator: Dominic-Madori Davis
item.description: Founders Tade Oyerinde and Teddy Solomon spoke at Disrupt this year about keeping communities engaged.

item.title: Every fusion startup that has raised over $100M
item.dc:creator: Tim De Chant
item.description: Fusion startups have raised $7.1 billion to date, with the majority of it going to a handful of companies.

item.title: The dumbest things that happened in tech this year
item.dc:creator: Amanda Silberling
item.description: From Sam Altman's olive oil "scandal" to Soham Parekh's viral moment, a lot of silly stuff has gone down in tech this year.

item.title: Almost 80 European deep tech university spinouts reached $1B valuations or $100M in revenue in 2025
item.dc:creator: Anna Heim
item.description: According to Dealroom’s European Spinout Report 2025, 76 European deep tech and life sciences spinouts have either reached $1 billion valuations, $100 million in revenue, or both.

item.title: VCs predict enterprises will spend more on AI in 2026 — through fewer vendors
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Szkutak
item.description: Enterprises have been experimenting with AI tools for a few years. Investors predict they will start to pick winners in 2026.

item.title: How to make your startup stand out in a crowded market, according to investors
item.dc:creator: Dominic-Madori Davis
item.description: At TechCrunch Disrupt, three investors took the stage to dissect what makes — and breaks — a pitch deck. Jyoti Bansal, a founder-turned-investor; Medha Agarwal of Defy; and Jennifer Neundorfer of January Ventures shared with the crowd their candid views on what works in a pitch deck — and what doesn't.
